maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Citrix XenServer 6 Management Pack provides the monitoring features that are required to monitor Citrix XenServer 6 Operating Systems.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Citrix XenServer 6 Computer" with instances of computers that are running a Citrix XenServer 6 operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule populates the "Citrix XenServer 6 Computer Group" with instances of computers that are running a Citrix XenServer 6 operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Disk Performance analysis report displays a chart for the following Performance counters:

maml:listItem.maml:para: LogicalDisk\Avg. Disk Queue Length\_Total
LogicalDisk\Disk Reads/sec\_Total
LogicalDisk\Disk Writes/sec\_Total
LogicalDisk\Avg. Disk sec/Transfer\_Total
LogicalDisk\Disk Bytes/sec\_Total

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of type
Citrix XenServer 6 Logical Disk
Search for disks by the logical name (e.g. "/home").
The report displays a chart and data table for every distinct object supplied.The report shows a historical chart without aggregation.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select objects of type Citrix XenServer 6 Logical Disk.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Create a state view or performance view by choosing
Date/Time selection: Allows selecting a relative or fixed date and time range and time zone.
Business hours: Allows to filter the results to one set of Business hours for a defined number of weekdays
Object: Allows adding objects to run this report for

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This report requires the following discovery to be enabled
“Discover Citrix XenServer 6 Logical Disks”

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Critical events related to security detected in the system log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A security failure may happen due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated output data item, events and alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other security events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Direct login utilizing the root account password detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Users may have been granted access to privileged accounts. This monitor allows system administrators to track direct logins utilizing the root account password.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the event encountered. If this event appears suspicious, please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A SSH Authentication failure for the root account has been detected in the system log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure may be caused by a mistyped password or an attempt to use an invalid username. However, a persistent failure could be an indication that someone is attempting to gain unauthorized access.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the problem encountered. If a failure occurs, please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Direct login into the root account detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Users may have been granted access to privileged accounts. This monitor allows system administrators to track direct logins as root user.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the event encountered. If this event appears suspicious, please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A successful 'su' command has been detected in the system log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Users may have been granted access to privileged accounts. This monitor allows system administrators to track 'su' usage.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the event encountered. If 'su' usage appears suspicious, please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Citrix XenServer 6 Logical Disk" with instances of logical disks discovered on Citrix XenServer 6 Computers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Disk Bytes Per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Disk Bytes Per Second performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which bytes were transferred to or from the disk during write or read operations.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the health of all Logical Disks. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the System back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that a Logical disk has become unhealthy. This may be caused by a disk being unmounted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the Disk Health from the Health Explorer. Health explorer provides the critical information and a mechanism to remount a logical disk. You can remount a logical disk from Health Explorer utilizing the State Change disk mount feature.
Optionally, you can utilize the logical disk description provided by the Health Explorer to manually mount the logical disk on the affected host with the 'mount' command.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Disk Read Bytes Per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Disk Read Bytes Per Second performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which bytes were transferred from the disk during read operations.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Disk Reads Per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Disk Reads Per Second performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which read operations were performed on the disk.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Disk Transfers Per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Disk Transfers Per Second performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which read and write operations were performed on the disk.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Disk Writes Per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Disk Writes Per Second performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which write operations were performed on the disk.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Disk Writes Per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Disk Writes Per Second performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which write operations were performed on the disk.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Free Megabytes performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Free Megabytes performance counter exposes the total amount of unallocated space on a specific logical disk in Megabytes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Percent Free Space performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Percent Free Space performance counter exposes the percentage of the total usable space on the selected logical disk drive that is free.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Disk % Free Space of all Logical Disks. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to free up some disk space and bring the System back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the % Free Space is currently low. This may be caused by an excessive logging by an application.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the Disk Capacity from the Operations Manager Console. Determine if any new applications have been recently installed. Review any log files for logs that appear to be excessively large. If so, determine if the logs are current or historical logs.

To remedy the situation consider using the tar utility to compress (zip) the log files and free up disk space. To create a tar file use the command 'tar -cvf [destination filename].tar [source path/file]'.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Percent Used Space performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Percent Used Space performance counter exposes the percentage of the total usable space on the selected logical disk drive that is currently allocated.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk Used Megabytes performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Logical Disk Used Megabytes performance counter exposes the total amount of allocated space on a specific logical disk in Megabytes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Network Interface\Bytes Received/sec performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Network Interface\Bytes Received/sec performance counter exposes the rate at which bytes are received over each network adapter, including framing characters. Network Interface\Bytes Received/sec is a subset of Network Interface\Bytes Total/sec.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Network Interface\Bytes Sent/sec performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Network Interface\Bytes Sent/sec performance counter exposes the rate at which bytes are received over each network adapter, including framing characters. Network Interface\Bytes Received/sec is a subset of Network Interface\Bytes Total/sec.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Network Interface\Bytes Total/sec performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Network Interface\Bytes Total/sec performance counter exposes the rate at which bytes are sent and received over each network adapter, including framing characters. Network Interface\Bytes Received/sec is a sum of Network Interface\Bytes Received/sec and Network Interface\Bytes Sent/sec.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the Linux Computer class named "Citrix XenServer 6 Network Adapter" with instances of Citrix XenServer 6 Network Adapters.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor generates an alert when the agent detects that the network adapter has been disconnected from the network and no longer has network connectivity.

If the computer has multiple network adapters, the alert may arrive before network connectivity for the effected adapter has been reestablished. However, remote clients and applications may still have difficulty accessing resources on the computer despite the other adapter or adapters. In addition, the local computer may not be able to access some network resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Your computer's network adapter lost its connection to the network.

The adapter's connection to the network can be lost if you remove a network cable from your network adapter or if you are roaming between wireless access points with a mobile system. Other possible causes include network issues, firewall issues, or a malfunction of the network adapter or its driver.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If your computer is connected to the network by cable, confirm that the cable is plugged in properly. If you have a wireless network connection, confirm that you have a signal and the proper credentials for the wireless network.
If the network connection is working properly, check the following possible causes and take corrective action:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The network is down. Attempt to ping or traceroute to the host.
The firewall on your computer is blocking network broadcast traffic.
Your computer's network adapter or driver is not functioning correctly. Login to the system as root and type 'ifconfig -a' to view all available network interfaces.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory Available MBytes performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Memory Available MBytes performance counter shows the amount of physical memory, in Megabytes, immediately available for allocation to a process or for system use.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Available MBytes (Memory\% Available MBytes) for the system. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state..

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The amount of available physical memory can become low under the following circumstances:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Too many applications/processes are running simultaneously on the computer.
An application may be leaking memory over time.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To address a low physical memory condition an administrator may choose one or more of the following options:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Stop or kill one or more applications, daemons, or processes. Execute the "top" command or execute "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View. It will provide a listing of processes ordered by CPU usage, the listing by default will display only the top CPU consuming processes and their corresponding PID (Process ID). Utilizing the output from the "top" command identify any offending or unnecessary processes along with its PID number. Issue a "kill" command utilizing the PID for the process. For example, if the PID number for the process is 4510, then issue the command 'kill 4510'. You can verify that available memory has been increased by running the "Memory Information" Task from the State View.
Add additional Physical Memory to the computer.
Move applications to one or more additional servers.

maml:section.maml:para: You can view Available Memory by running the "Memory Info" Task from the State View.
VMStat provides detailed Memory Statistics averaged since the last reboot. You can run the VMStat Task from the State View.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Available Swap in MBytes performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Available Swap in MBytes performance counter exposes the total amount of available swap space in MBytes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the amount of available swap space. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action may be required in order to bring the System back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the swap space utilization is currently high. Circumstances that may cause this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Processes using excessive physical memory resources.
Writing to a temp filesystem.
Too many applications are running simultaneously on the computer.
An application may be leaking memory over time.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions

maml:listItem.maml:para: Close or stop one or more applications, daemons, or processes. Execute the "top" command or execute "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View. It will provide a listing of processes ordered by CPU usage, the listing by default will display only the top CPU consuming processes and their corresponding PID (Process ID). Utilizing the output from the "top" command identify any offending or unnecessary processes along with its PID number. Issue a "kill" command utilizing the PID for the process. For example, if the PID number for the process is 4510, then issue the command 'kill 4510'.

Add additional swap space. Using mkfile create a file for local swap area. To create a 1GB swap file: dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1k count=1048576. Issue the command to make it a swap file: mkswap /swapfile. Issue the command to activate the swap file: swapon /swapfile. You should run the 'free' command to see all available swap space.
Add additional Physical Memory to the computer.

maml:section.maml:para: You can view Available Memory by running the "Memory Info" Task from the State View.
VMStat provides detailed Memory Statistics averaged since the last reboot. You can run the VMStat Task from the State View.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Citrix XenServer 6 Operating System" with instances of discovered Citrix XenServer 6 operating systems.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Page Reads/sec performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Memory\Page Reads/sec performance counter exposes the rate, in incidents per second, at which the disk was read to resolve hard page faults. This counter shows numbers of read operations, without regard to the number of pages retrieved in each operation. This counter is a primary indicator for the kinds of faults that cause system-wide delays.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Pages per Second performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Pages per Second performance counter exposes the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. This counter is a primary indicator of the kinds of faults that cause system-wide delays. It is the sum of Memory\Pages Input/sec and Memory\Pages Output/sec.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Page Writes/sec performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Memory\Page Writes/sec performance counter exposes the rate at which pages are written to disk to free up space in physical memory. This counter shows write operations, without regard to the number of pages written in each operation. This counter displays the difference between the values observed in the last two samples, divided by the duration of the sample interval.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Percent Available Memory performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Percent Available Memory performance counter exposes the total amount of available memory as a percentage of the total memory on the system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Percent Available Swap performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Percent Available Swap performance counter exposes the total amount of available swap space as a percentage of the total swap space on the system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Percent Used Memory performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Percent Used Memory performance counter exposes the total amount of memory currently in use by the system as a percentage of the total physical memory on the system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Percent Used Swap Space performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Percent Used Swap Space performance counter exposes the total amount of used swap space as a percentage of the total swap space on the system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent DPC Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Total Percent DPC Time performance counter exposes the percentage of time that the processor spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs) during the sample interval. DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. They are counted separately and are not a component of the interrupt counters. This counter displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Total Percent DPC Time for the system. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.

Percent DPC Time is the percentage of time that the processor spends receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs, or soft interrupts, are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. If a High % DPC Time is sustained there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A High % DPC Time value can be caused by one or more of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Processor bottleneck
Software-related problem
Hardware or device driver related problem

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To determine the root cause of a High DPC rate, follow the process outlined below. Observe the proportion of the processor time that is spent servicing interrupts and DPCs. To do this, monitor the following counters in real time using System Monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Processor\% Processor Time
Processor\% Interrupt Time
Processor\% DPC Time

maml:section.maml:para: Compare the values of the % Interrupt Time and % DPC Time counters to Processor\% Processor Time for each processor instance.

If a processor instance is running a sustained % Processor Time that is > 85% and it is also spending > 15% of that time servicing Interrupts and/or DPCs, the processor is probably the source of a performance bottleneck. This bottleneck can be addressed by upgrading or adding additional processors to the computer.

If the processor is running a sustained % Processor Time of < 85% and it is also spending > 15% of that time servicing interrupts and/or DPCs, the performance issue may be the result of either an application or hardware related issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent Idle Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Total Percent Idle Time performance counter exposes the percentage of time that the processor was idle during the sample interval.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent Interrupt Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Total Percent Interrupt Time performance counter exposes the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention. Normal thread execution is suspended during interrupts. Most system clocks interrupt the processor every 10 milliseconds, creating a background of interrupt activity suspends normal thread execution during interrupts. This counter displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Total Percent Interrupt Time for the system. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.

Percent Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards, and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A High % Interrupt Time most often indicates that there is a problem with a hardware device.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The % Interrupt Time counter will not specifically identify the device that is causing a High % Interrupt Time. System log files should be checked to identify device errors.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent IO Wait Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Total Percent IO Wait Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor utilized to execute received instructions and produce the associated output.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent Nice Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Total Percent Nice Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor utilized executing nice command requests.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent Privileged Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Total Percent Privileged Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spent executing code in privileged mode.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent Processor Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Total Percent Processor Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spends to execute a non-Idle thread. It is calculated by measuring the duration of the idle thread is active in the sample interval, and subtracting that time from interval duration. (Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run). This counter is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed during the sample interval. It is calculated by monitoring the time that the service is inactive, and subtracting that value from 100%.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the CPU utilization. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the System back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the CPU utilization is currently high. This may be caused by an application using excessive CPU resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To address high percent processor times choose one or more of the following options:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Identify processes that are running when the Percent Processor Time is at the highest. Execute the "top" command or execute "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View. It will provide a listing of processes ordered by CPU usage, the listing by default will display only the top CPU consuming processes and their corresponding PID (Process ID).

Stop or kill any unnecessary identified processes. Utilizing the output from the "top" command identify any offending or unnecessary processes along with its PID number. Issue a "kill" command utilizing the PID for the process. For example, if the PID number for the process is 4510, then issue the command 'kill 4510'.
Add additional CPUs or Physical Memory to the computer.
Move applications to one or more additional servers.

maml:section.maml:para: You may view the Top CPU Consumers by executing the "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Total Percent User Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Total Percent User Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spent executing code in user mode. Applications, environment subsystems, and integral subsystems execute in user mode.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Used Swap in MBytes performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Used Swap in MBytes performance counter exposes the total amount of used swap space in MBytes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Used Memory in MBytes performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed to one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Used Memory in MBytes performance counter exposes the total amount of memory currently in use by the system in MBytes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Operating System Configuration report displays these discovered properties:

maml:listItem.maml:para: OS Version

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of type
Citrix XenServer 6 Operating system
Search for objects which contain “Citrix XenServer 6”
The report displays a matrix detailing all the found properties.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select objects of type Citrix XenServer 6 Operating System.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Create a state view or performance view by choosing the “Citrix XenServer 6 Operating system” type.
Date/Time selection: Allows selecting a relative or fixed date and time range and time zone.
Object: Allows adding objects to run this report for

Memory Available Megabytes

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of type
Citrix XenServer 6 Operating System

The report displays a for every selected object a separate chart.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select objects of type Citrix XenServer 6 Operating System.

Date/Time selection: Allows selecting a relative or fixed date and time range and time zone.

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of type
Citrix XenServer 6 Operating System
Search for objects which contains and “Citrix XenServer 6”
The report displays for every selected object a separate chart. Data is aggregated to days of a month.
When run from the Reporting space:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/Read performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/Read performance counter exposes the average time, in seconds, of the average disk read.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Physical Disk Average Read Time. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.
Physical Disk Average Read shows the time, in seconds, of the average disk read. A disk that is developing a bottleneck might cause the entire system to slow.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the physical disk average disk read rate is currently high.
Circumstances that may cause this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Logic board or controller related problems.
The hard drive interface speed can form a bottleneck to overall performance if it is too low for the hard disk's maximum sustained transfer rate.
When available memory is low, the Virtual Memory Manager writes more pages to swap, resulting in increased disk activity.
Upgrade or replace existing drive controllers with faster models.
Confirm system has the maximum speed hard drive that it can support.
Install separate drives on individual controller cards, spreading the read/write activities across multiple controllers, to increase overall performance.

Be sure to set this threshold value appropriately for your specific storage hardware. The threshold value will vary according to the disk’s underlying storage subsystem. For example, the “disk” might be a single spindle or a large disk array. You can use Operations Manager overrides to define exception thresholds, which can be applied to specific computers or entire computer groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/Transfer performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/Transfer performance counter exposes the average time, in seconds, of the average disk transfer.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Physical Disk Average Transfer Time. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.
Physical Disk Average Transfer shows the time, in seconds, of the average disk transfer. A disk that is developing a bottleneck might cause the entire system to slow.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the physical disk average disk transfer rate is currently high.
Circumstances that may cause this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: High CPU utilization can cause slowdowns when doing large data transfers.
The hard drive interface speed can form a bottleneck to overall performance if it is too low for the hard disk's maximum sustained transfer rate.
When available memory is low, the Virtual Memory Manager writes more pages to swap, resulting in increased disk activity.
Upgrade to a faster CPU or add additional processors.
Confirm system has the maximum speed hard drive that it can support.
Add additional Physical Memory.

Be sure to set this threshold value appropriately for your specific storage hardware. The threshold value will vary according to the disk’s underlying storage subsystem. For example, the “disk” might be a single spindle or a large disk array. You can use Operations Manager overrides to define exception thresholds, which can be applied to specific computers or entire computer groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/Write performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/ Write performance counter exposes the average time, in seconds, of the average disk write.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Physical Disk Average Write Time. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.
Physical Disk Average Write shows the time, in seconds, of the average disk write. A disk that is developing a bottleneck might cause the entire system to slow.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the physical disk average disk write rate is currently high.
Circumstances that may cause this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Logic board or controller related problems.
The hard drive interface speed can form a bottleneck to overall performance if it is too low for the hard disk's maximum sustained transfer rate.
When available memory is low, the Virtual Memory Manager writes more pages to swap, resulting in increased disk activity.
Upgrade or replace existing drive controllers with faster models.
Confirm system has the maximum speed hard drive that it can support.
Install separate drives on individual controller cards, spreading the read/write activities across multiple controllers, to increase overall performance.

Be sure to set this threshold value appropriately for your specific storage hardware. The threshold value will vary according to the disk’s underlying storage subsystem. For example, the “disk” might be a single spindle or a large disk array. You can use Operations Manager overrides to define exception thresholds, which can be applied to specific computers or entire computer groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Citrix XenServer 6 Physical Disk" with instances of physical disks discovered on Citrix XenServer 6 Computers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Physical Disk\Disk Bytes/sec performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Physical Disk\Disk Bytes/sec performance counter exposes the rate bytes are transferred to or from the disk during write or read operations.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the health of all Physical Disks. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the System back to an operational state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that a Physical disk has become unhealthy. This may be caused by disk cable, controller, or power related failures, as well as actual physical disk failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the Disk Health from the Health Explorer. Health explorer provides the critical information and a mechanism to remount a logical disk. You can remount a logical disk from Health Explorer utilizing the State Change disk mount feature. Optionally, you can utilize the logical disk description provided by the Health Explorer to manually mount the logical disk on the affected host with the “mount” command.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the Cron daemon. This is done by running a WSMan query, checking if the Cron daemon is running. If you receive an alert from this monitor, check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the Cron daemon is currently unavailable.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running 'ps -ef | grep cron' or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. If it is down, you can start the process using the command 'service crond restart' or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfiles (/var/log/messages) and (/var/log/cron), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This process monitor watches for the Kernel Message Logging Daemon process to be running.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the klogd service is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running ps -ef | grep klogd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running ‘/sbin/klogd’ or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfile (/var/log/messages) and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This process monitor watches for the port mapper process to be running. The portmap daemon converts RPC program numbers into Internet port numbers.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the portmap service on the system is down

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service by running ps -ef | grep portmap or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running the command "service portmap start" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfile (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This process monitor watches for the rpc.idmapd process to be running.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the rpc.idmapd service on the system is down

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running ps -ef | grep rpc.idmapd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start the process using the run level startup script "/etc/init.d/rpcidmapd restart" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfile (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This process monitor watches for the rpc.statd process to be running. The rpc.statd server implements the NSM (Network Status Monitor) RPC protocol.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the rpc.statd service on the system is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running ps -ef | grep rpc.statd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start the process using the run level startup script "/etc/init.d/nfslock restart" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfile (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This process monitor watches for the SSHD process to be running. SSHD is the daemon for ssh. It replaces rlogin and rsh, and provides secure encrypted communication between two untrusted hosts over an insecure network. There should be at least one process running at all times.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the ssh service on the system is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service by running ps -ef | grep sshd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running the command "service sshd start" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfiles (/var/log/messages) and (/var/log/secure), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the status of the Syslog daemon. This is done by running a WSMan query, checking if the Syslog daemon is running. If you receive an alert from this monitor, check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the Syslog daemon is currently unavailable.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running 'ps -ef | grep syslog' or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. If it is down, you can start the process using the command ‘service syslog restart’ or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfile (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This process monitor watches for the udev process to be running. Udev is a generic kernel device manager. It runs as a daemon on a Linux system and listens to events the kernel sends out if a new device is initialized or installed

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the udev service is down.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service by running ps -ef | grep udev or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running "/sbin/start_udev" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system logfile (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Citrix XenServer 6 Processor" with instances of processors discovered on Citrix XenServer 6 Computers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Total Percent DPC Time for the system. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.

Percent DPC Time is the percentage of time that the processor spends receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs, or soft interrupts, are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. If a High % DPC Time is sustained there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A High % DPC Time value can be caused by one or more of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Processor bottleneck
Software-related problem
Hardware or device driver related problem

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To determine the root cause of a High DPC rate, follow the process outlined below. Observe the proportion of the processor time that is spent servicing interrupts and DPCs. To do this, monitor the following counters in real time using System Monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Processor\% Processor Time
Processor\% Interrupt Time
Processor\% DPC Time

maml:section.maml:para: Compare the values of the % Interrupt Time and % DPC Time counters to Processor\% Processor Time for each processor instance.

If a processor instance is running a sustained % Processor Time that is > 85% and it is also spending > 15% of that time servicing Interrupts and/or DPCs, the processor is probably the source of a performance bottleneck. This bottleneck can be addressed by upgrading or adding additional processors to the computer.

If the processor is running a sustained % Processor Time of < 85% and it is also spending > 15% of that time servicing interrupts and/or DPCs, the performance issue may be the result of either an application or hardware related issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent Idle Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Processor Total Percent Idle Time performance counter exposes the percentage of time that the processor was idle during the sample interval.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Total Percent Interrupt Time for the system. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.

Percent Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards, and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A High % Interrupt Time most often indicates that there is a problem with a hardware device.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The % Interrupt Time counter will not specifically identify the device that is causing a High % Interrupt Time. System log files should be checked to identify device errors.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent Nice Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Processor Total Percent Nice Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor utilized executing nice command requests.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent Privileged Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Processor Total Percent Privileged Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spent executing code in privileged mode.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Percent Processor Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Processor Percent Processor Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spends to execute a non-Idle thread. It is calculated by measuring the duration of the idle thread is active in the sample interval, and subtracting that time from interval duration. (Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run). This counter is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed during the sample interval. It is calculated by monitoring the time that the service is inactive, and subtracting that value from 100%.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the Percent Processor Time for each processor. If you receive an alert from this monitor, action can be required in order to bring the system back to an operational state.
The Percent Processor Time is the percentage of time the processor was busy during the sampling interval.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: High processor-time values can occur under the following circumstances:

maml:listItem.maml:para: New processes are started.
Processes are blocked while waiting for I/O.
There are too many processes on the system.
Low Memory is causing excessive swapping and high I/O.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To address high percent processor times choose one or more of the following options:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Identify processes that are running when the Percent Processor Time is at the highest. Execute the "top" command or execute "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View. It will provide a listing of processes ordered by CPU usage, the listing by default will display only the top CPU consuming processes and their corresponding PID (Process ID).

Stop or kill any unnecessary identified processes. Utilizing the output from the "top" command identify any offending or unnecessary processes along with its PID number. Issue a "kill" command utilizing the PID for the process. For example, if the PID number for the process is 4510, then issue the command 'kill 4510'.
Add additional CPUs or Physical Memory to the computer.
Move applications to one or more additional servers.

maml:section.maml:para: You may view the Top CPU Consumers by executing the "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent User Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Processor Total Percent User Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor spent executing code in user mode. Applications, environment subsystems, and integral subsystems execute in user mode.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent DPC Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Processor Total Percent DPC Time performance counter exposes the percentage of time that the processor spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs) during the sample interval. DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. They are counted separately and are not a component of the interrupt counters. This counter displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent Interrupt Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.

The Processor Total Percent Interrupt Time performance counter exposes the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention. Normal thread execution is suspended during interrupts. Most system clocks interrupt the processor every 10 milliseconds, creating a background of interrupt activity suspends normal thread execution during interrupts. This counter displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor Total Percent IO Wait Time performance counter. This information is collected and is exposed one or more Views and/or Reports.
The Processor Total Percent IO Wait Time performance counter exposes the percentage of elapsed time that the processor utilized to execute received instructions and produce the associated output.

maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers supported agent information for Citrix XenServer 6 on x64 computers.
